content.question: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (12 points, suggested time 25 minutes) The two circuits shown above contain an ideal variable power supply, an ohmic resistor of resistance <math alttext="Uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, an ammeter <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and two voltmeters <math alttext="V sub P S, end subscript" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>PS</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="V sub uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. In circuit <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> the ammeter has negligible resistance, and in circuit 2 the ammeter has significant internal ohmic resistance <math alttext="Lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The potential difference of the power supply is varied, and measurements of current and potential difference are recorded. (a) The axes below can be used to graph the current measured by the ammeter as a function of the potential difference measured across the power supply. On the axes, do the following. Sketch a possible graph for circuit 1 and label it 1. Sketch a possible graph for circuit 2 and label it 2.

frqParts.text: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (12 points, suggested time 25 minutes) The two circuits shown above contain an ideal variable power supply, an ohmic resistor of resistance <math alttext="Uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, an ammeter <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and two voltmeters <math alttext="V sub P S, end subscript" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>PS</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="V sub uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. In circuit <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> the ammeter has negligible resistance, and in circuit 2 the ammeter has significant internal ohmic resistance <math alttext="Lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The potential difference of the power supply is varied, and measurements of current and potential difference are recorded. (a) The axes below can be used to graph the current measured by the ammeter as a function of the potential difference measured across the power supply. On the axes, do the following. Sketch a possible graph for circuit 1 and label it 1. Sketch a possible graph for circuit 2 and label it 2.

(b) Let <math alttext="delta V sub P S, end subscript" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>PS</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the potential difference measured by voltmeter <math alttext="V sub P S, end subscript" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>PS</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> across the power supply, and let <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the current measured by the ammeter <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. For each circuit, write an equation that satisfies conservation of energy, in terms of <math alttext="delta V sub P S, end subscript" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>PS</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="Uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="Lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as appropriate. Circuit 1 Circuit 2
(c) Explain how your equations in part (b) account for any differences between graphs 1 and 2 in part (a).

(d) In circuit 2, <math alttext="uppercase R equals, 40 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. When voltmeter <math alttext="V sub P S, end subscript" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>PS</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> reads <math alttext="3.0 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, voltmeter <math alttext="V sub uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> reads <math alttext="2.5 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the internal resistance <math alttext="Lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the ammeter.

(e) Voltmeter <math alttext="V sub uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in circuit 2 is replaced by a resistor with resistance <math alttext="120 ohms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>120</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to create circuit 3 shown below. Voltmeter <math alttext="V sub P S, end subscript" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>V</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>PS</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> still reads <math alttext="3.0 volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.30em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. i. Calculate the equivalent resistance <math alttext="uppercase R sub equivalent" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the circuit.
ii. Calculate the current in each of the resistors that are in parallel.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
